comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
Twas the pig fair last September
A day I well remember
I was walking up and down in drunken pride
When my knees began to flutter
And I sank down in the gutter
And a pig came up and lay down by my side

As I lay there in the gutter
Thinking thoughts I could not utter
I thought I heard a passing lady say
You can tell the man who boozes
By the company he chooses
And with that the pig got up and walked away.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: The pump was still there in 1909, and the O'Shea's and Mrs Hanlon are in 1911, but not 1901 census. Also the Gaelicisation of O'Shea to O'Seaghdha ties in with mid-period of 1900-1920 Celtic Revival. Is it too simplistic to think 1910 is a good date for this one?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 33546386@N03
comment._content: Fantastic My Compliments

comment.author: 90761497@N06
comment._content: The Street lamps, were erected by the Edenderry Town Council (formed in 1908) in 1909...they used Acetylene gas.......hotel at the bottom of the picture going down the hill was Kinsella's.....the scaffolding (the highest ones) are at the Hibernian Bank (now Bank of Ireland)....work was carried out here in late 1909/1910 see Freemans Journal, 5 August 1909 which calls for tenders....In 1909 part of the town hall was converted into a library and reading room....the Downshire coat of arms was not removed until 1938 although most of the sale of the Downshire estate was complete by 1922...  Ciaran

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/90761497@N06] Excellent information, Ciaran, thanks!

So, 1910 as a date for this photo is not out of the question then, given the lamps and the scaffolding?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
